title: Aristotle's Three Pillars of Persuasion
description: Learn Aristotle's Three Pillars of Persuasion in one minute.

hook.text: Aristotle cracked the code of persuasion 2,300 years ago. Advertisers, politicians, and lawyers still use his formula.

buildup.text: In his work Rhetoric, Aristotle identified three modes of persuasion: ethos, pathos, and logos.

discovery.text: Ethos is credibility. Pathos is emotion. Logos is logic. Every convincing argument uses at least one.

twist.text: Aristotle argued that pathos â€” emotion â€” is often more persuasive than logos. Feelings beat facts.

climax.text: Modern advertising, courtroom strategy, and political speeches are all built on Aristotle's 2,300-year-old framework.

punchline.text: The secret to persuasion hasn't changed in 23 centuries.

quiz.question: What are Aristotle's three modes of persuasion?
